bestBHT.bht: When the church gathers, everyone must contribute their gifts for the purpose of edifying one another. This includes using the gifts of prophesying, singing hymns, and teaching. The Holy Spirit desires order and peace, promoting the edification of the church. Each person has been given different gifts, such as composing and singing psalms, deducing doctrines, and interpreting languages. Let all things be done unto edifying, with each gift having its place in an orderly manner.

Henry Alford: The rule for all, proceeding on the fact of each having his gift to contribute when they come together: viz. that all things must be done with a view to edification."
a hymn of praise to sing in the power of the spirit, as did Miriam, Deborah, Symeon, &c.
an exposition of doctrine or moral teaching: belonging to the gift of prophecy.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: What then is the true rule to be observed as to the use of gifts?
A psalm—extemporary, inspired by the Spirit.
Let all things be done unto edifying.
Albert Barnes: The Holy Spirit is the author of order, and not of confusion.
True religion prompts to peace and regularity, and not to discord and tumult.
Let this be the great principle, to promote the edification of the church.
John Calvin: Each gift must have its place, but in order and in measure.
The Church must not be taken up to no purpose with unprofitable exercises, but must, in whatever is done, have an eye to edification.
Let every one, according as he has been endowed with some particular gift, make it his aim to lay it out for the advantage of all.
Philip Schaff: Each one hath a psalm to 'sing in the spirit,' hath a doctrine some truth to utter 'in the spirit,' hath a revelation something revealed to him to be imparted to others, hath a tongue, hath an interpretation to speak in, while another has the interpretation to give."
In place of this confusion, Let all things be done unto edifying."
A sufficient general direction for the ordering of public worship.
Archibald T. Robertson: When ye come together (οταν συνερχησθε). Present middle subjunctive, repetition, whenever ye come together, in contrast with special case (εαν συνελθη, second aorist subjunctive) in verse 1 Corinthians 14:23.
John Gill: Everyone of you hath a psalm; not that everyone had this, or any other gift here mentioned, but that there were some among them that had one or other of these several gifts: some of them had a gift of composing and singing a psalm extempore; they delighted in psalmody, and were forward to promote it, and fond of spending the time wholly in it.

Hath a doctrine; others of them had a gift of deducing doctrines out of the word of God, which is profitable for that purpose, in an extraordinary manner, without study, and were capable of teaching them, and instructing men in them in a very edifying way.
Hath an interpretation; others had a gift of interpreting languages, particularly the Hebrew language, when anything was delivered therein by another.
John Wesley: Every one hath a psalm — That is, at the same time one begins to sing a psalm; another to deliver a doctrine; another to speak in an unknown tongue; another to declare what has been revealed to him; another to interpret what the former is speaking; every one probably gathering a little company about him, just as they did in the schools of the philosophers.
Let all be done to edification — So as to profit the hearers.

bhtAttempts.bht: When the church comes together, everyone should contribute their gifts with the goal of edifying one another. This includes using the gifts of prophesying, singing hymns in the power of the Spirit, and delivering an exposition of doctrine or moral teaching. The Holy Spirit, who is the author of order, desires for all things to be done with peace and regularity, promoting the edification of the church. Each person has been endowed with different gifts, such as composing and singing psalms extemporaneously, deducing doctrines from the Word of God, interpreting languages, and declaring revelations. Therefore, let all things be done unto edifying, where every gift has its place in an orderly and measured manner.

When the church gathers, everyone must contribute their gifts for the purpose of edifying one another. This includes using the gifts of prophesying, singing hymns, and teaching. The Holy Spirit desires order and peace, promoting the edification of the church. Each person has been given different gifts, such as composing and singing psalms, deducing doctrines, and interpreting languages. Let all things be done unto edifying, with each gift having its place in an orderly manner.

When the church comes together, everyone should contribute their gifts with the aim of edification. This includes prophesying, singing hymns in the power of the Spirit, and delivering an exposition of doctrine. The Holy Spirit desires order and peace, not confusion and discord. Each person has been endowed with different gifts, such as composing and singing psalms extemporaneously, deducing doctrines from the Word of God, and interpreting languages. Therefore, let all things be done unto edification, so that the church may be built up and grow in its faith.
